newsarticle.author: Cherry Blum
newsarticle.headline: European markets close higher thanks to the strength of the Dow
newsarticle.content:
LONDON (CBS.MW) -- British and French stocks closed sharply higher Thursday as they tracked Wall Street's post-Rubin Dow rally.

In morning trade, London shares rebounded from a Yeltsin and Rubin driven sell off. London's FTSE 100 index closed up 113.50 points, or 1.8 percent, at 6,456.60.

In Paris, the CAC rose in quiet trade due to a public holiday in France. The Paris CAC 40 gained 61.09 points, or 1.4 percent, to close at 4,415.88.

The German markets were closed Thursday for the Ascension Day national holiday.

U.K. pharmaceuticals surge

Pharmaceutical stocks in London surged but analysts said gains by pharmaceuticals stocks are a blip in the recent sector rotation. In late afternoon trade, AstraZeneca shares were up 118 pence, or 4.8 percent, at 2577. Glaxo Wellcome (GLX: news, msgs) gained 39 pence, or 2.1 percent, to 1848. Smithkline Beecham (SBH: news, msgs) stocks rose 22.5 pence, or 2.8 percent, to 826.

On Wednesday, AstraZeneca sold its specialty chemicals unit for 2.1 billion to a management buy-out backed by Cinven and Investcorp. Smithkline meanwhile, received confirmation of U.S. patents for its Paxil drug. A positive report for Glaxo's Valtrex drug boosted the company's shares.

Looking ahead, analysts said sector rotation will likely move money out of defensive stocks -- such as pharmaceuticals -- and into cyclical stocks such as chemicals.

"It can be considered something of a bounce. They [pharmaceuticals stocks] are fairly valued on historical measures and need good earnings news to lift them which won't come until the mid-term results in August," said Mark Becker, pharmaceuticals analyst at JP Morgan in London.

Other major gainers in London included telecom stocks which were boosted by continuing merger speculation in the sector. Colt Telecom Group (COLTY: news, msgs) led gainers. It was up 60 pence, or 5 percent, at 1250. Cable & Wireless PLC (CWP: news, msgs) rose 28 pence, or 3.4 percent, to 833.

"There's a large amount of upside potential left," said Richard Crehan, U.K. equity strategist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter in London.

The company with the heaviest weighting on the FTSE 100, BP Amoco (BPA: news, msgs), picked up 20.5 pence, or 1.8 percent, to 1114.

In Europe's currency markets, the dollar gained 0.6 percent to 121.62 yen and rose 0.2 percent to 1.8394 deutsche marks. Sterling rose 0.1 percent to 1.6189. The euro shed 0.2 percent to 1.0626.
